moves.7... c6: Well, this is the warsaw variation.
moves.8. Rb1: New theory from Kramnik...The idea being that in the Dutch leningrad, White has to watch out for the Bishop diagonal. E.g., 8. d5 e5; 9. e.p. dxe6 Bxe6; 10 b3. and Black has counter play. How is White suppose to protect his c4-pawn? I should note 10. Qd3 is played too.
I didn't know what else to play and I thought it open play....
moves.17... Rf5: at least now I can play the move...
moves.18. b4: Yes, ....It makes all the difference with that b1-rook instead of it being on a1.
moves.18... Na6 19. Be3: Again, this is why I played e4 first.....I didn't know what to do with my dark-squared Bishop. Hence, why I played e4 as I thought it looked funny in front of the Pawn as opposed to being "behind" the pawn...
moves.21. Rc1 a6 22. Qd2 d5 23. a4 Nc7 24. Bb6: X-raying. Planning to capture Bishop on e5. After which RxR, and White would have a triple fork after Bishopxnc7!!
moves.25... Bd6 26. f4 Rc8 27. Rc2 Qf8 28. Rec: ?......herein lies the problem for White: how is he going to tip the scale in his favor? I'm looking for that feather to lay down on the scale and have my opponent fall down...
moves.29. a5: !! I was thinking boy...my bishop would cause a whole deal of trouble on d7.
moves.31. Bd7 Ra8 32. Rc2xc7: ! I foresaw the position and seen that my Rook wouldn't fair to well after the Bishop exchanges and Rook capture. Plus, I saw my dark-squared bishop was better on e5 attacking the King's fortress.
I think black was afraid of g4.
moves.36. Qxb7 Rd8 37. Rc8 Rxc8 38. Qxc8 Qxc8: and now I win by endgame
